content.title: CT Angiography (CTA)
content.definition: Non-invasive imaging technique using intravenous contrast and multi-detector CT to visualize arteries and veins. The primary imaging modality for evaluating most vascular pathology, offering rapid acquisition, wide anatomic coverage, and excellent spatial resolution.

key_concepts.description: IV iodinated contrast injection (80-120 mL); bolus tracking or test bolus for timing; helical acquisition during arterial phase; typical slice thickness 0.5-1mm; multiplanar reformats (MPR) and 3D reconstructions

Rapid acquisition (seconds); wide anatomic coverage; excellent spatial resolution; 3D reconstruction capability; visualization of vessel wall, calcification, and surrounding structures; widely available
Radiation exposure; iodinated contrast (nephrotoxicity, allergy); calcification blooming artifact may overestimate stenosis; limited functional information
Gold standard for acute aortic syndrome (dissection, IMH, PAU), aneurysm evaluation, post-EVAR surveillance, aortoiliac occlusive disease, trauma
Lower extremity runoff for PAD; upper extremity for thoracic outlet, trauma; carotid/vertebral CTA for stroke workup; renal/mesenteric CTA for renovascular/mesenteric disease
Cardiac gating reduces motion artifact for thoracic aorta and coronary arteries; essential for ascending aorta evaluation; increases radiation dose
Two energy acquisitions allow material characterization; better visualization through calcification; iodine mapping for perfusion; bone subtraction
Check renal function (hold if eGFR <30 mL/min unless emergent); hydration pre/post; hold metformin; premedicate if contrast allergy history
Delayed imaging for venous structures; DVT evaluation; venous malformations; May-Thurner diagnosis; portal vein assessment
Volume rendering, maximum intensity projection (MIP), and curved planar reformats aid surgical planning; centerline measurements for EVAR sizing; virtual angioscopy

content.statement: CT Angiography (CTA) is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Diagnostics Cta that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding CT Angiography (CTA) helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of CT Angiography (CTA) include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of CT Angiography (CTA).

learning_objectives: Understand CTA technique and contrast considerations
Know indications for CTA in various vascular territories
Recognize limitations including calcification artifact and nephrotoxicity
Appreciate the role of ECG-gating for thoracic imaging
clinical_pearls: CTA is first-line imaging for acute aortic syndrome
Calcification blooming can overestimate stenosis - correlate clinically
Check renal function - contrast nephropathy risk
Dual-energy CTA helps see through calcium
common_mistakes: Not checking renal function before contrast
Over-relying on calcification artifact for stenosis grading
Not obtaining appropriate phase (arterial vs venous)

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
